channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Slater and Gordon, Australian Law Firm, to Acquire Arm of Quindell of Britain
item.description: Slater and Gordon, the first law firm to list on a stock exchange, plans to buy the professional services unit of the British firm for about $947 million.
item.dc:creator: BRETT COLE

item.title: Russian Theater Director Fired for Offending Christians
item.description: The Culture Ministry said Boris Mezdrich had failed to mitigate an outcry among the Russian Orthodox Church who were offended by various aspects of the production of “Tannhauser.”
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

item.title: Singaporeans and World Leaders Gather for Final Farewell to Lee Kuan Yew
item.description: Thousands braved heavy rains to say goodbye to Singapore’s founder and first prime minister, whose funeral drew a long list of dignitaries from across the globe.
item.dc:creator: SONIA KOLESNIKOV-JESSOP
item.media:description: Crowds braved torrential rains on Sunday for the funeral procession of the country’s first prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew.

item.title: Arab Nations to Form Military Force to Counter Iran and Islamist Extremists
item.description: Many analysts attributed the move, intended to counter both Iranian influence and Islamist extremism, in large part to the Arab states’ drive for more independence from Washington.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: An American Military Convoy in Europe Aims to Reassure Allies
item.description: Operation Dragoon Ride, consisting of 120 armored vehicles and more than 500 American troops, was envisioned as part public relations event, part training exercise and part signal to Russia.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: More than 500 American troops are taking an 1,100-mile tour of Europe, known as Operation Dragoon Ride, in a show of strength designed to allay concerns about Russian aggression.

item.title: Beef Ban in India Reaches Into Cages of Lions and Tigers
item.description: The prohibition has had a broad effect on everyday life, including for animals at a national park in Mumbai.
item.dc:creator: NEHA THIRANI BAGRI and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Cows in a shelter in Mumbai, India. The Maharashtra state government recently banned the possession and sale of beef.

item.title: Turkey Moves to Close All Gates at Border With Syria
item.description: After maintaining an open-door policy through the four years of civil war in neighboring Syria, Turkey has begun shutting out refugees amid fears of a possible terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and KARAM SHOUMALI

item.title: Kabul Journal: Woman Killed in Kabul Transformed From Pariah to Martyr
item.description: Farkhunda has emerged as the rarest of Afghan figures: a female religious champion who ventured into a shrine to preach Islam and was felled by ignorant men.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: Afghan women’s rights activists carried the coffin of Farkhunda, an Afghan woman who was beaten to death and set on fire.

item.title: Iran Backs Away From Key Detail in Nuclear Deal
item.description: With a negotiating deadline on Tuesday, Iranian officials have backed away from a critical element of a proposed nuclear agreement, saying they are no longer willing to ship their atomic fuel out of the country.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Foreign ministers from other world powers joined Secretary of State John Kerry in an effort to reach the outlines of a nuclear accord with Iran by a midnight Tuesday deadline.

item.title: Memo From Germany: Jet Crash Tests Germany’s Faith in Its Precision
item.description: Andreas Lubitz, in deliberately crashing a plane, has upended Germany’s well-ordered world and challenged other assumptions built into German life.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Hendrik Schmidt/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People in the German town of Halle left flowers and candles at a shrine to commemorate a woman from the town who died in the Germanwings plane crash.

item.title: Germanwings Crash Settlements Are Likely to Vary by Passenger Nationality
item.description: The payout for an American aviation disaster victim averages $4.5 million versus $1.3 million for a German victim.
item.dc:creator: JAD MOUAWAD and NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Conservative Alliance Gains in French Voting
item.description: An alliance of conservative parties took control of at least two-thirds of France’s local departments, trouncing the Socialists on Sunday in the second round of France’s local elections.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Air Canada Plane Lands Short of Runway in Nova Scotia
item.description: An Airbus A320 landed among a group of antennas, shearing off its landing gear, but no one was seriously injured, officials said.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Cricket: Rising From Wreckage, Australia Sweeps to World Cup Title
item.description: Australia completed its climb from the depths to the heights of world cricket on Sunday when it won its fifth World Cup, defeating New Zealand by seven wickets in the final at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.
item.dc:creator: HUW RICHARDS
item.media:description: Australian captain Michael Clarke lifted the Cricket World Cup championship trophy after defeating New Zealand in the final.

item.title: Official Says Commander of Group That Massacred 21 in Tunisia Is Dead
item.description: Khaled Chayeb, also known as Lokman Abu Sakhr, was killed with eight other Islamist militants by members of the national guard in an ambush overnight, Tunisia’s prime minister said.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Tunisians marched through the capital on Sunday. Khaled Chayeb was killed with eight other militants, officials said.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Meaning of Fingergate
item.description: Two finance ministers are the perfect foils for the new German self-confidence as it emerges in the course of the European debt crisis.
item.dc:creator: ANNA SAUERBREY
item.media:description: Wolfgang Schäuble, Germany’s finance minister, left, and Yanis Varoufakis, Greece’s finance minister, meeting in Berlin in February.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Moscow's Twisted History Lessons
item.description: Putin bends the narrative of Russia's past to justify his mission to reclaim the country's lost glory.
item.dc:creator: MAXIM TRUDOLYUBOV

item.title: Uzbeks Vote on Expected 4th Term for Authoritarian Leader
item.description: President Islam Karimov, in power since 1989, faced three opposition candidates who used their campaigns to praise the incumbent.
item.dc:creator: MANSUR MIROVALEV and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A polling place in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, on Sunday. About 91 percent of eligible voters participated.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Share the Pork, Be President for Life
item.description: African voters won't tolerate the strongmen of the past, but they'll bend the rules for leaders who bring prosperity.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES ONYANGO-OBBO

item.title: The Week Ahead: A Deadline for Greece, and U.S. Jobs Data
item.description: Greece is hoping to gain approval for its economic plans on Monday so its rescuers will release the next round of bailout aid; United States employment data is due on Friday.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
